In this work, spin-polarized density functional theory calculations are conducted to evaluate the possible applicability of a single P atom doped silicon carbide (P-SiC) monolayer for reduction of nitrous oxide (N2O). The calculations show that P-doping in SiC monolayer is energetically favorable, and the resulting P-SiC is both dynamically and thermodynamically stable. According to our findings, N2O spontaneously dissociates when it interacts with the P-SiC from its O site without the need for an energy barrier, releasing -2.59 eV of energy. The adsorption energy of CO molecule on the P-SiC is less negative than that of N2O, implying that N2O will predominately occupy the catalyst surface. The CO + Oad reaction is used to remove the remaining oxygen atom (Oad) from the P-SiC surface. The calculations show that the reaction proceeds through a low activation energy barrier of 0.33 eV, which is much lower than the previously reported catalysts. This demonstrates the high catalytic activity of P-SiC surface. Furthermore, the adsorption of H2O and O2 species on the P-SiC nanosheet is investigated. The results show that the presence of these species has no effect on the catalytic activity of the P-SiC surface for N2O reduction. These results show that the proposed novel P-SiC catalyst can be regarded as an efficient material in the development of promising active catalysts for N2O elimination from the environment. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract . Keywords Density functional theory P-SiC surface N2O Dissociation Energy barrier 1 Introduction Nowadays, the environmental pollution is enormously increased, which greatly received scientists’ attention. Therefore, the primary efforts to protect environment is mostly focused on the control emission of toxic pollutants from various sources e.g. combustion of fossil fuels in automotive engines and industrial sectors [1]. The nitrogen oxides (NOx), originating from power plants, mobile sources etc. have been identified to be the main causes of greenhouse effect, ozone depletion, acid rain, haze and photochemical smog [2]. In NOx, nitrous oxide (N2O) is an important greenhouse gas that is mainly produced during microbial nitrogen transformation processes in natural and agricultural soils [3–5]. Natural emissions of N2O is about 11 Mt N2O-N/yr (megatons of N2O in equivalent nitrogen per-year) while 6 Mt N2O-N/yr emitted by anthropogenic activities [6,7]. The natural N2O emission sources are atmospheric, marine and terrestrial sources while anthropogenic activities that contribute to its emissions mainly include the transformation of fertilizers nitrogen into N2O, fossil fuels combustion, biomass burning, wastewater treatment, industrial activities and aquaculture [5,6,8]. N2O is the largest stratospheric ozone depleting substance, being concomitantly the third most potent greenhouse gas [9]. Specifically, N2O has approximately 310 times higher global potential than CO2, while exhausting at the same time ozone layer in a similar way to chlorofluorocarbons [9]. More worrisome, the continuous N2O emission due to the anthropogenic activities are greatly increasing and are imaged to almost double by 2050, unless remission schemes put forward by each country [7,9]. Recently, novel and efficient catalysts are reported, which are widely used to reduce the emissions of NOx, carbon monoxide and other pollutants [10]. Thus, to control the N2O emissions to the environment, the direct catalytic dissociation process is one of the most popular technologies. Thus, the understanding of N2O origin and its control should noticeably contribute to the Earth's climate stabilization [9]. The reduction of N2O by carbon monoxide (CO) has gained a lot of interest in recent decades because it offers a simple and promising method of removing dangerous CO and N2O molecules from waste gasses at a single process [11–13]. Both experimental [12,14,15] and theoretical studies [16–19] have suggested that the main underlying mechanism for the reduction of N2O by CO is the decomposition of N2O molecules on the catalyst surfaces into N2 and Oad moieties, followed by the elimination of Oad by CO. The important aspect of this process is that the formed products, N2 and CO2, are less harmful than CO and N2O, implying that it can provide a good solution for cleaning the atmosphere from the latter toxic gasses. The only challenge is that N2O decomposition generally requires active catalysts for activation of the N‒O bond, where noble metal-based catalysts play a critical role. Numerous studies have shown that N2O decomposition can be easily catalyzed over noble metals like Pt [20–22], Pd [13,23,24], or Au [25–27] or their alloys. Though the CO molecules may remove the produced Oad species left over the catalyst, this reaction is identified as the rate-limiting step of the entire N2O reduction process due to the strong binding of Oad to the catalyst surface. Furthermore, noble metals are expensive, rare, and generally require high temperatures for optimal performance, all of which limit their large-scale application in N2O reduction. As a result, it is desirable to seek for and develop noble metal-free catalysts for N2O reduction with CO. Literature reveals that carbon-nanomaterials including graphene and graphene like 2D materials have attracted enormous attention because of their unique structures, tunable physical and chemical properties and best electrical conductivity. Particularly, various types inorganic 2D nanosheet like magnesium oxide (MgO), aluminum nitride (AlN), boron nitride (BN) and silicon carbide (SiC) have earned substantial interest due to their large specific area, wide band gap and cost effective synthetic route [28–33]. SiC nanomaterial with wonderful physical, chemical and thermal properties is a good alternative to graphene, which can be utilized in high frequency and high temperature environments [33,34]. Recently, researchers used SiC as gas sensor [33], as anode materials for alkali ion and magnesium ion batteries [34,35] and as catalyst [36,37]. Using density functional theory (DFT) simulations Zhao et al. [33] investigated SiC as gas sensor. There results demonstrates that the SiC nanosheet shows an excellent adsorption performance for NO, NO2 and NH3 molecules with fast recovery time. DFT study [35] evince high theoretical capacity of SiC nanosheet as an anode materials in magnesium ion battery. Wang et al. [38] explored the catalytic properties of SiC monolayer for the CO oxidation reaction. The results suggested that the 2D SiC nanosheet is a promising metal free catalyst for CO oxidation process. Similarly layered SiC nano-sheets exhibits a good catalytic activity for the oxygen reduction reaction [37]. The study of Wang et al. [36] reveal that SiC is an efficient catalyst for carbon dioxide conversion with high efficiency and selectivity. Motivated by the previous studies, we aimed to study the possible application of phosphorous (P) doped SiC monolayer as a metal-free catalyst for N2O reduction using density functional theory (DFT) approach. P atom was chosen because it is inexpensive and plentiful in the earth's crust and in phosphate minerals. Using DFT suitable adsorption configurations of N2O and CO molecules over the P-SiC catalyst are studied. The basic mechanism for the reduction of N2O and oxidation of CO is then studied carefully. Since H2O and O2 species are present in waste gasses, the effect of these molecules on the N2O reduction process is also investigated. The results show that doping of SiC with P atom transforms it into an active catalyst to reduce N2O molecules. 2 Computational details The DMol3 code was employed for spin-polarized DFT computations [39,40]. All the computations were performed using the PBE functional and a double numerical plus polarization function (DNP) basis set [41]. To ensure the dynamic stability of the examined structures, vibrational frequency simulations were performed at the same level of theory. The basis set cutoff and thermal smearing were set at 4.6 Å and 0.005 au, respectively. To compensate van der Waals interactions, the Grimme's scheme DFT-D2 method was used [42,43]. The Brillouin-zone was integrated to 3 × 3 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack k-points for geometry relaxations, while 5 × 5 × 1 k-points for the electronic properties calculations. The adsorption energies (E ad) of all complexes were calculated using the equation: (1) E a d = E c o m p l e x − ( E a d s o r b e n t + E a d s o r b a t e ) where E complex, E adsorbent and E adsorbate are the total electronic energies of the relaxed structure of the complex system (gas adsorbed over the nanosheet) and bare nanosheet and reactant species i.e., N2O, CO, O2 and H2O, respectively. Gibbs free energy changes (ΔG) were obtained using the following equation to determine if adsorption of reaction species is achievable at normal temperature: (2) Δ G = Δ E + Δ E Z P E − T Δ S wherein ΔE is energy released during the adsorption process at T = 0 K. The ΔEZPE and ΔS are the changes in zero-point energy and entropy during complex formation as derived from the vibrational frequency calculations. The zero-point energy and entropy values of the isolated molecules were obtained using the NIST standard reference database [44]. The reaction barriers were obtained from the linear synchronous transit/quadratic synchronous transit [45], while nudge elastic band [46] method was used to derive minimum energy pathways. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Structural properties and adsorption behavior of N2O onto pristine SiC monolayer The relaxed geometry of silicon carbide (SiC) monolayer is represened in Fig. S1. The Si—C bond length in 2D monolayer is 1.77 Å, which is in good agreement with earlier studied [33,37]. As previous stduies shows that the 2D silicon carbide nanosheet is energeticall, dynamically and thermally is stable [33,47–50]. The adsorption behavior of a N2O molecule on pure SiC monolayer is initially examined. Fig. 1 depicts the optimized geometry of N2O on SiC monolayer, as well as the related partial density of states (PDOS) and electron density plots (Panels a–d). The geometry relaxation shows that N2O is weakly adsorbed over the pristine SiC monolayer, with a large binding distance of 3.31 Å, and that there are no significant variations in the N‒O or N‒N bond length of N2O due to its physisorption (Fig. 1(a, b)). The E ad value of N2O in this obtained complex is −0.17 eV, confirming the physisorption. Furthermore, the Hirshfeld analysis demonstrates that there was a minor charge transfer (< 0.003 electrons) between the N2O and SiC monolayer during the adsorption process. The PDOS plot in Fig. 1c shows that there is no considerable overlap between the electronic states of N2O and SiC monolayer at the Fermi level, implying that there is no strong interaction between them. This is supported by electron density isosurfaces (Fig. 1d), which demonstrate that in the N2O adsorbed structure, electrons are mostly localized over the adsorbate (N2O) and adsorbent (SiC monolayer) independently, showing the lack of a chemical bonding between them. These findings suggest that the pure SiC monolayer sheet has a low proclivity to activate the N2O molecule. 3.2 Structural, energetic and electronic properties of P-SiC layer Recent studies shows that doping nanostructures with various atoms singificanlty activated the N2O molecule [8,51–53]. Therefore, we doped the SiC monolayer with the phosporous (P) atom. The optimized geometries of the P-embedded SiC (P-SiC) mono layer, corresponding density of states, electron density difference (EDD) and spin density plot is illustrated Fig. 2 (a–d). Two different doping sites were considered for the P doping into the SiC monolayer that is site-1(Si atom of hexagonal ring was replaced by P atom) and site-2 (C atom of hexagonal ring was replaced by P atom), as shown in Fig. S1. Then fully geometry relaxation simulations were performed for both sites. The formation energy (E f) value for P doping at site-1 is noticed as 2.11 eV while that for site-2 is 5.52 eV, respectively. The E f value demonstrates that the doping of P atom into site-1 is energetically more favourable than site-2. In site-1 doping, the P—C bond length is calculated is 1.77 Å, which is almost equivalent to the Si—C bond length. While due to larger atomic radius of P atom than the C atom, there is smaller distortion occurred in the geometry of SiC monolayer and the P atom is bulges out from the plan. The Hirshfeld surface charge analysis shows that the P atoms carries positive charge of 0.21e which can be attributed to its lower electronegativity (2.19) than C atoms (2.55). The total density of states analysis (Fig. S2) shows that at Fermi level of P-SiC monolayer there is a distinct peak, assigned to the P-3p states. The appearance of this peak results to a significant decrease (1.25 eV) in the band gap of the SiC monolayer (2.85 eV) as shown in the band strucutrues (Fig. S2). This result together with the PDOS analysis (Fig. 2b) show that 3p state of P atom is strongly overlap with the 2p state of C atoms at Fermi level, suggesting a stronger covalent bond formation beween the P atom and C atom of the monolayer. The EDD plot (Fig. 1c) are in agreement with the PDOS analysis, which shows that a relatively larger-positive charge is accumulated on the P atom hence it formed stronger covalent bonds with the neighbouring electronegative C atoms. The spin electron density map (Fig. 2d) shows tha there is a high spin density localized over the P atom as compared to neighbor atoms, depicts the enhanced chemical-reactivity of the P doped surface. Furhtermore, to check the dynamic and thermal stabilty of the P doped SiC monlayer we computed the phono spectrum for doped surface and performed the ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations at 1000 K for period of 2 fs. The plots of phonon spectra and AIMD analysis are illustrated in Figs. S and 3 (a, b). The phonon analysis indicates that all the vibration modes (Fig. S3) are rea in the entire Brillouin zones confirming the dynamical stability of P-SiC monolayer. The AIMD calculations shows that the potential energy variates around a certain magnitude while there is negligbile variations occurred in the bond lengths and the P atom is fixed at its posoition, suggesting that this system is able to withstand high temperature up to 1000 K. The optimized geomrty and corresponding PDOS plot of P doping at site-2 is shown in Fig. S4. Compared to site-1, larger distrotion is observed after P doping at site-2, resulted the P—C bond elongation to 2.27 Å. The PDOS analysis display that there is considrible overlaping exits between the p states of P and Si atoms at Fermi level. Hirsfeld charge transfer analysis shows that there is −0.05 e charge is present over P atom after doping at site-2. 3.3 Adsorption properties of N2O and CO over P-SiC monolayer The adsorption of reactant species onto the catalyst is critical in the N2O reduction process, as it is in any other catalytic process. Hence, the DFT calculations are conducted to explore the potential adsorption properties of N2O and CO molecules over the P-SiC monolayer. Fig. 4 (a–c) depicts the optimized geometries of N2O and CO adsorbed onto the P-SiC monolayer, as well as the associated PDOS plots and electron density difference (EDD) graphs (Panels a–c). Table 1 shows the minimum binding distances (R min), adsorption energies (E ad), charger-transfer (Q CT) values and Gibbs free energy change (ΔG). According to the literature, N2O can bind to the active sites of the catalyst in a variety of ways. As a result, several initial configurations are considered to locate the most stable (energetically favorable) adsorption configurations, including those in which N2O approaches the different sites of P-SiC monolayer from its N, O sites, or through its N‒O and N‒N bonds. Our calculations show that N2O interacted with the P atom via its N site with binding distance of 3.76 Å and an E ad value of −0.18 eV and a ΔG value of −0.12 eV (Table 1). The larger binding distance and E ad value of N2O on P-SiC monolayer demonstrate that the N2O removal by P-SiC via its N site is not favorable. According to the Hirshfeld analysis, there is no significant charge transfer observed between the catalyst surface and N2O molecule due to weak interaction. The PDOS plot in Fig. 4(a) supports this finding, in which no mixing among 3p states of P atom are noticed with the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) of N2O at Fermi level. As a result, no substantial hybridization between the P and N atoms occurs, resulting physisorption. The EDD analysis (Fig. 4(a)) demonstrates that the concentration of electron density near the P—N bond is absent which validates the physisorption nature between the N2O and P-SiC monolayer. A dissociative N2O adsorption has been reported on the other P doped nanostructure, as the N2O molecule approaches the surface from its O site [51]. This might be ascribed to the newly formed strong P-O bond as well as the substantial polarization of the N‒O bond of N2O in the presence of a positive P atom. As Table 1 indicates, the E ads value for N2O adsorption from its O site is −2.59 eV, which is better than the previously reported single atom doped catalysts for N2O dissociation (Table 2 ) [17,22,54,55]. The calculated ΔG value for the N2O dissociative reaction is −2.25 eV, suggesting that the process occurs spontaneously at normal temperature and that the resultant species (Oad and N2) are thermodynamically stable. To see the effect of temperature on the N2O reduction, the ΔG values are calculated for N2O dissociation step using the following Eq. (2) at various temperature (298.15 – 800 K) as reported earlier [56]. Table S1 lists the ΔG values of N2O dissociation step at various temperature. From Table S1, it is seen that the reduction of N2O is exothermic over a wide range of temperature. While an increase in the temperature makes a decrease in the ΔG values of N2O reduction process. The negative ΔG values along with no energy barrier discussed above indicate that N2O reduction over P-SiC catalyst is a thermodynamically and kinetically favored process over a wide range of temperature. Furthermore, the charge transfer analysis shows that the Hirshfeld charges on the P and Oad atoms are +0.31 and −0.36 |e|, respectively. The PDOS analysis (Fig. 4(b)) shows that the electronic states of Oad and P are mixed at the Fermi level, but no mixing is evident for the electronic states of Oad and N2, confirming the dissociation of the N2O specie over the P-SiC sheet. This is further supported by the EDD analysis in Fig. 4(b), which shows that the electron density is concentrated between the P atom and the Oad, with no overlapping between the EDD of N2 and the Oad, indicating the N2O dissociation. Another critical step in the N2O reduction process is the adsorption of CO molecules onto the catalyst surface. As a result, in this investigation, the adsorption of CO on the P-SiCis also investigated. The most energetically stable adsorption structure of CO is depicted in Fig. 4(c). The geometry optimization reveals that the CO molecule attaches to the P atom from its C site, adopting an end-on configuration. The calculated P—CO bond length is 2.63 Å, evince weak adsorption which is consistent with the previously reported P doped catalysts [51,55,57]. The E ad value of CO over P-SiC monolayer is −0.19 eV, which is less than that of the N2O molecule dissociation energy, indicating that CO adsorption is less favorable. The ΔG value for the CO adsorption is negative (−0.13 eV), implying that CO adsorption is possible at room temperature. Following the adsorption, CO molecule gains 0.04 electrons from the surface, resulting in a negligible (0.01 Å) elongation in the C‒O bond. Meanwhile, the PDOS plots in Fig. 4(c) demonstrate that there is no significant hybridization at the Fermi level between the CO-5σ and vacant 3p orbitals of the P atom. Furthermore, the empty CO-2π* states accept some charge from the CO-5σ, therefore CO-5σ moved to Fermi-level and CO-2π* energy level enhanced above Fermi level. The weak interaction of CO over the P-SiC is also justified by the corresponding EDD isosurface (Fig. 4(c)), where there is a negligible electron density mixing observed between them. To gain more insights into the selectivity of P-SiC catalyst for N2O reduction in presence of CO molecule. The co-adsorption of N2O and CO molecules over the catalyst surface are investigated. The optimized geometry of N2O and CO molecule co-adsorption over P-SiC is shown in Fig. S5. The geometry relaxation revealed that the N2O is spontaneously dissociated over the P-SiC surface from its O site as found for separately N2O molecule adsorption over the catalyst surface. While the CO molecule is moved away from the P atom of the surface and shows physisorption nature. The bond distance between the O and N atom after dissociation is 3.24 Å and P—O bond distance is 1.52 Å, respectively. On the other hand, the distance between the C atom of CO molecule and O atom attached at surface is 2.94 Å while between C and P atom the binding distance is 3.74 Å. The adsorption energy value obtained for N2O/CO co-adsorption is −2.77 eV (Fig. S5). Thus, the co-adsorption study shows that the P-SiC catalyst can selectively reduce N2O molecule. The interaction of N2O molecule at site-2 is also considered in the preset study, the optimized geometry and corresponding PDOS and EDD plots are illustrated in Fig. 5 (a–d). As the above information exposed that the N2O molecule strongly interacted with P atom from its O site, therefore for site-2 we just simulated the N2O interaction from O site (Fig. 5(a, b)). The geometry optimization depicted that there is no significant interaction is observed between the N2O molecule and catalyst surface the binding distance is noticed is 3.71 Å, while the E ad value obtained for this interaction is −0.091 eV, which is comparatively very small, signifying that site-2 of the catalyst surface is not favorable for N2O + P → N2 + O*P reaction. This is further confirmed by PDOS (Fig. 5(c)) analysis which shows that there is no hybridization exist between the p states of P and O atom at Fermi-level. The EDD analysis (Fig. 5(d)) demonstrates that there no overlapping of electron density appeared between the N2O molecule and catalyst surface, evidence of weak bonding between them. 3.4 Catalyst recovery To prevent the catalyst from poising due to the presence of the Oad moiety, the interaction of the CO molecule with the Oad should be examined. This is accomplished by allowing the CO molecule to react with the Oad. The potential energy diagram for the reaction of the CO molecule with the Oad is shown in Fig. 6 . The CO molecule has an intermolecular bond distance of 2.92 Å and an E ad value of −0.14 eV at the initial state (IS-1), showing that it weakly interacts with the Oad. Based on the Hirshfeld analysis, CO adsorption is followed by a minor charge shift from Oad to CO. To complete the process, the CO molecule is moved closer to the Oad until the formation of C-O and C-Si bond is occurred, resulting in the formation a CO2 molecule (IM in Fig. 6) over the catalyst surface. According to the IR frequency analysis, the transition state TS-1, which involves the weakening of the P‒Oad bond and the formation of a new C=O bond, is associated with an imaginary frequency of 136.85i cm−1 (Fig. S4). A very low energy barrier of 0.28 eV is required for this reaction step, which is readily available at room temperature. This barrier is quite similar to that of the previously reported catalysts for N2O reduction. Furthermore, with a reaction energy of −0.26 eV, this reaction is exothermic. It must be noticed that the observed energy barrier of this reaction is much smaller than those reported (Table 2) for Si@N4-grpahene (0.66 eV) [19], Si@C24N24 (0.37 eV) [58], Au55 (0.79 eV) [59], Ag55 (0.53 eV) [60], Pd (0.91 eV) [61] and Pt (0.79 eV) [61], respectively. This demonstrates that the catalytic performance of the P-SiC is superior to that of the catalysts mentioned. Meanwhile, the binding distance between of P and Si atom with O and C atom is increased as the IM converted to FS-1 (released CO2 molecule from surface) by overcoming a small activation energy (0.33 eV). Furthermore, the adsorption energy value of CO2 over the P-SiC surface is very low (−0.17 eV), suggesting that catalyst recovery is quite feasible at room temperature. In addition to the CO molecule, N2O may attack the Oad species and form N2 and O2 molecules. Hence, the N2O + Oad → N2 + O2, ad is investigated on the catalyst surface. Fig. 7 depicts the relevant potential energy diagram for this process. In IS-2, N2O is weakly adsorbed over the Oad moiety with a binding distance of 3.31 Å and an E ad value of −0.18 eV, indicating its physisorption. As the N2O approached the Oad to generate N2 and O2, it passes through the TS-2 with an energy barrier of 0.87 eV. The reaction energy for this process is 0.39 eV, suggesting that it is not kinetically feasible under normal conditions. The PDOS, molecular orbital and EDD analyses of the initial and transition states involved in the CO + Oad → CO2 reaction are performed to get a better understanding of the high catalytic activity of the P@SiC. The obtained findings are depicted in Fig. 8 (a–e). The findings demonstrate that in the IS-1, the empty 2π* orbital of CO overlaps with the HOMO of O-preadsorbed P@SiC. With the progress of the reaction, electrons are moved from the surface to the CO, as seen by the significant overlap of electronic states at the Fermi level in TS-1. The molecular orbital analysis in Fig. 8(c)) supports this finding, where the 2π* orbital of the CO molecule is mixed with the HOMO of the Oad covered P@SiC. Consequently, the C‒O and P‒Oad bonds are elongated as the reaction progresses from IS-1 to TS-1. Furthermore, the EDD plots Fig. 8(d, e) show that as the reaction proceeds from IS-1 to TS-1, a considerable electron density buildup between the P atom and CO molecule confirms the formation of bond between them. So, the outstanding catalytic activity of P-SiC might be related to the substantial hybridization of electronic states of Oad and CO molecule. 3.5 Effect of O2 and H2O molecules on catalyst The adsorption of oxygen (O2) and water (H2O) molecules on the Si-doped BN-yne is also investigated to see whether their presence would interfere with N2O reduction. Fig. 9 (a–c) depicts the most energetically advantageous adsorption configurations of O2 and H2O, as well as the associated intermolecular distances. It is found that the H2O is physisorbed over the catalyst surface, with an E ad value of −0.20 eV and a minimum binding distance of 2.39 Å (Table 1). Considering the Hirshfeld analysis, there is very small charge transfer between H2O molecule and the surface. Furthermore, the calculated ΔG value for H2O adsorption is positive (+0.27 eV), suggesting that the adsorption process is not feasible at normal temperatures. Two different adsorption configurations for O2 are investigated i.e., side-on configuration (Fig. 9(b)) in which O2 is adsorbed on the top of P and Si atom, parallel to the SiC surface and end-on configuration (Fig. 9(c)) in which one of the O atoms of O2 is attached to the P atom and O2 is placed almost perpendicular to the SiC surface. The calculated E ad value for the side-on configuration onto the catalyst surface is −1.89 eV, with Si‒O and P‒O bond lengths of 1.79 and 1.73 Å, respectively. The Hirshfeld analysis indicates that a charge of 0.07 and 0.09 electrons is moved from the Si and P atom to the O2 molecule. The obtained ΔG value for side-on configuration is −1.38 eV, showing the exothermic nature. The E ad value, P‒O bond length and ΔG value calculated for end-on adsorption configuration is −1.38 eV, 1.83 Å and −0.93 eV. There is 0.04 e charge transferred from the P atom to the O atom of the O2 molecule. However, comparing the adsorption energies of H2O and O2 molecules to those of N2O molecule clearly suggests that the latter species cannot interrupt the N2O reduction reaction. Furthermore, the larger dissociation energy of N2O compared to O2 adsorption energy suggests that the competing CO + O2 process cannot take place in the presence of N2O molecules. 4 Conclusion The N2O reduction over P-SiC monolayer was investigated using the quantum chemical calculations. It was revealed that replacing a Si atom in the hexagon ring of SiC with a P atom is more energetically advantageous than other sites. The P-SiC surface is dynamically and thermodynamically stable, according to phonon dispersion vibration analysis and AIMD simulations. It is discovered that the active catalytic site for dissociated N2O molecule is P@SiC. Furthermore, the P-SiC demonstrated rapid catalytic activity in the CO + Oad → CO2 process. The activation energy for this reaction is relatively small (0.33 eV), indicating that this process is comparably more favorable than the previously reported. Comparing the adsorption energies of H2O and O2 molecules with that of N2O, it is found that the presence of H2O or O2 molecules cannot interrupt the N2O reduction process. Based on these exciting findings, P-SiC is suggested as a highly active, low-cost and environmentally friendly catalyst for eliminating N2O and CO molecules from waste gasses. coredata.dc:description: In this work, spin-polarized density functional theory calculations are conducted to evaluate the possible applicability of a single P atom doped silicon carbide (P-SiC) monolayer for reduction of nitrous oxide (N2O). The calculations show that P-doping in SiC monolayer is energetically favorable, and the resulting P-SiC is both dynamically and thermodynamically stable. According to our findings, N2O spontaneously dissociates when it interacts with the P-SiC from its O site without the need for an energy barrier, releasing -2.59 eV of energy. The adsorption energy of CO molecule on the P-SiC is less negative than that of N2O, implying that N2O will predominately occupy the catalyst surface. The CO + Oad reaction is used to remove the remaining oxygen atom (Oad) from the P-SiC surface. The calculations show that the reaction proceeds through a low activation energy barrier of 0.33 eV, which is much lower than the previously reported catalysts. This demonstrates the high catalytic activity of P-SiC surface. Furthermore, the adsorption of H2O and O2 species on the P-SiC nanosheet is investigated. The results show that the presence of these species has no effect on the catalytic activity of the P-SiC surface for N2O reduction. These results show that the proposed novel P-SiC catalyst can be regarded as an efficient material in the development of promising active catalysts for N2O elimination from the environment.
coredata.dc:title: Density functional theory study of P-embedded SiC monolayer as a robust metal free catalyst for N2O reduction and CO oxidation
